_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan Executive Summary for Corteva Agriscience, Pittsburg Operations



Revision History:



12-Jul-2019 - Resubmitted RMP due primarily to 5 year update requirement.  However, several changes are captured in this update as follows.  Note:  this facility was previously owned and operated by Dow Chemical.  A change of ownership notification was submitted on 03/08/19.



a) 310 Block Operations:



- Added a unit operation within the 310 Block Operations that handles hydrogen fluoride as a covered process due to interconnectivity.  The 310 Block Operation was already covered due to hydrogen fluoride.  The inclusion of the unit operation did not increase the hydrogen fluoride inventory nor did it change the WCS or ARS.  



- The facility is already, and remains, a Program 3 stationary source with accident prevention programs in place. 



b) 640 Block Operations:



- Updated the worse case scenario for aqueous ammonia.  The updated WCS for aqueous ammonia does not have any off-site impact and does not supersede the current WCS (SO2) for the site.



- The facility is already, and remains, a Program 3 stationary source with accident prevention programs in place. 



Note: Unit Operations included in Federal RMP due to interconnectivity rule.  Section 1.17 includes actual inventory (below threshold quantity).



- 310 Block Operations [Chlorine]

- 520 Block Operations [Hydrogen Chloride]

- 560 Block Operations [Chlorine]





1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Corteva Agriscience, Pittsburg Operations is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by Pittsburg Operation's comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at Pittsburg Operations.  It is Pittsburg Operations' policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible

releases of regulated substances.  Pittsburg Operations is also committed to responding to emergencies resulting from accidental releases in order to mitigate the release and any associated consequences.





2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled



The primary activity at Pittsburg Operations is agricultural chemical manufacturing.  Pittsburg Operations has six regulated substances present at the site.  These substances include ammonia (aqueous), ammonia (anhydrous), chlorine, hydrogen chloride (anhydrous), hydrogen fluoride (anhydrous) and sulfur dioxide (anhydrous).  Ammonia (anhydrous) is used in pollution control equipment for a boiler.  Ammonia (aqueous) is used in making an agricultural herbicidal intermediate.  Chlorine is used in making of intermediate and finished products for agricultural applications and is a byproduct of these processes.  Hydrogen chloride is made as a co-product of some of the agricultural product manufacturing processes.  Hydrogen fluoride and sulfur dioxide (anhydrous) are used to make agricultural products and intermediates.





3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program



Pittsburg Operations has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  Pittsburg Operations was designed and constructed in accordance with RAGAGEP.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the site.



Process Safety Information



Pittsburg Operations maintains detailed records of safety information that describe the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. Examples include; Material Safety Data Sheets, piping and instrumentation diagrams, equipment specification sheets, reactive chemicals testing reports, and corrosion reports.  This information is regularly reviewed, as needed, and is readily accessible to plant operation

s personnel.





Process Hazard Analysis



Pittsburg Operations conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the covered processes are identified and effectively controlled.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses include Reactive Chemical/Process Hazard Analysis (RC/PHA), Hazard and Operability Study (HAZOP), Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA), Reactive Chemical Reviews, and Project Safety & Loss Prevention Reviews.  Studies utilize an appropriate team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering, maintenance and process operations and are revalidated on a regular basis.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis, where a response is required, are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.





Operating Procedures



For the purposes of safely conducting activities within Pittsburg Operations' covered processes, written operating procedures are maintained.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  This information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to plant operations personnel.





Training



Pittsburg Operations has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating processes are competent in the operating procedures and safe work practices associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least once every 3 years, and more frequently as needed, for required process and safety topics.





Mechanical Integrity



Pittsburg Operations carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure safe and reliable operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, critical instruments, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps. Qualified personnel w

ith previous training in maintenance practices are utilized to carry out appropriate maintenance.  These personnel are also offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.





Management of Change



Written procedures are in place at Pittsburg Operations to safely manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.





Pre-startup Reviews



Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted by appropriate personnel as a regular practice at Pittsburg Operations.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.





Compliance Audits



Pittsburg Operations conducts audits of compliance systems for RMP requirements on a regular basis.  These audits are carried out at least once every 3 years by a team of qualified personnel.  Any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are tracked to ensure resolution in a timely and appropriate manner.





Incident Investigation



Pittsburg Operations promptly and carefully investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.





Employee Participation



Pittsburg Operations truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to expre

ss their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  The site has safety teams, which involve employees as leaders in facilitating team efforts. In addition, Pittsburg Operations employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular. Safe job performance is required for each of the jobs at the site.





Contractors



Pittsburg Operations hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance, construction and various other activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Pittsburg Operations has a policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes. Contractors are also required to inform Pittsburg Operations of any hazards they may introduce at the site. Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.





4. Five-year Accident History



Pittsburg Operations has an excellent record of preventing accidental releases due to the site's release prevention policies.  There have been no accidents from Pittsburg Operations within the last 5 years with off-site or on-site impacts (deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place) that meet RMP reporting criteria.





5. Emergency Response Plan



Pittsburg Operations utilizes a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, sheltering-in-place, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  To ensure proper functioning, Pittsburg Operations emergency response equipment is regu

larly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place that would require a modified emergency response.



CA Region II LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which the emergency plan for the Pittsburg Operations site has been coordinated and verified. Pittsburg Operations also coordinates our plans and actions with local agencies and industrial mutual aid groups, which provide Pittsburg Operations with additional emergency response capability.





6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety



Improving safety is a continuous process at Pittsburg Operations.  PHA's, Compliance Audits, Technology Reviews, Facility Self-Assessments and Management System Reviews, Incident Investigations, Emergency Response Drills and employee participation are a primary means for identifying opportunities to improve safety.  Structural seismic upgrades, materials of construction upgrades, installing additional process instrumentation and/or process controls, and conducting Hazard Awareness training are typical of currently planned changes to improve safety at the facility.  As another example of Pittsburg Operations' commitment to continuous improvement in safety, the site was CalOSHA Voluntary Protection Plan (VPP) Star certified in 2013 and recertified in 2017.



Additional information regarding process descriptions, Worst Case and Alternate Release Scenario impact maps, public receptors, etc., is available at the Pittsburg Operations Site.
